awd_abstract_narration:
This award is made as part of the FY 2020 Mathematical Sciences Postdoctoral Research Fellowships Program. Each of the fellowships supports a research and training project at a host institution in the mathematical sciences, including applications to other disciplines, under the mentorship of a sponsoring scientist. The title of the project for this fellowship to Juliette Bruce is " Asymptotic Syzygies in Algebraic Geometry" The host institution for the fellowship University of California - Berkeley, and the sponsoring scientist is David Eisenbud.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
While funded by this grant, the PI worked in the Department of Mathematics, at the University of California Berkeley under the mentorship of Professor David Eisenbud. During this time the PI worked on several projects in the intersection of commutative algebra and algebraic geometry, that improved our understanding of the relationship between the algebra and geometry of the solution sets to systems of polynomial equations (i.e. algebraic varieties). 

Much of the PI”s work involved furthering our understanding of the ways minimal free resolutions — which can roughly be thought of as an algebraic linearization of an algebraic variety — is related to the geometry of an algebraic variety. In particular, joint with Cranton Heller and Sayrafi, the PI proved several results extending classical theorems concerning Castelnuovo–Mumford to toric varieties. As part of this work, the PI and her collaborators developed many new tools in multigraded commutative algebra, which should hopefully prove useful to other researchers going forward. 

In a separate direction, the PI pursued a project in combinatorics to better understand the geometry of certain moduli spaces. Roughly speaking moduli spaces are algebraic varieties, whose points are in correspondence with a given class of geometric objects (e.g. curves, abelian varieties, etc.). Such spaces have played central roles in algebraic geometry since the 19th century. Together with several collaborators, the PI utilized combinatorial and algebraic tools to understand a certain geometric invariant (the top-weight cohomology) of the moduli space of abelian varieties. These results suggest previously unseen geometric structures for the moduli space of abelian varieties, which has inspired ongoing work. Similarly, the combinatorial tools utilized in this project has opened the door for the study of several combinatorial chain complexes related to matroids.

Beyond research, the PI engaged in substantial work to help promote women and LGBTQ+ people in mathematics. This included organizing a conference for LGBTQ+ mathematicians in algebra, geometry, and number theory, as well as mentoring several students on research projects on those topics discussed above. Additionally, the PI organized multiple online learning opportunities for undergraduate and graduate students in algebraic geometry and commutative algebra. The PI organized several research conferences while supported by this grant.
